chapter.title: Managing Storage
chapter.para: There are several ways of handling disk storage in the Cloud Area Padovana:

listitem.para: Ephemeral storage exists only for the life of a virtual machine instance. It will persist across reboots of the guest operating system but when the instance is deleted so is the associated storage. The size of the ephemeral storage is defined in the virtual machine flavor.

Volumes are persistent virtualized block devices independent of any particular instance. Volumes may be attached to a single instance at a time, but may be detached or reattached to a different instance while retaining all data, much like a USB drive. The size of the volume can be selected when it is created within the quota limits for the particular project.

section.title: Ephemeral storage
section.para: Ephemeral storage exists only for the life of a virtual machine instance. It will persist across reboots of the guest operating system but when the instance is deleted so is the associated storage. The size of the ephemeral storage is defined in the virtual machine flavor.

Among the flavor details (that are listed in the Dashboard when a VM has to be launched or can be seen using the nova flavor-list command), there is an attribute called 'Ephemeral'. When you use a flavor with an ephemeral disk size different from zero, the instance is booted with an extra virtual disk whose size is indicated by the ephemeral value. This ephemeral disk can be useful where you want to partition the second disk or have a specific disk configuration which is not possible within the system disk configuration.

warning.para: Please note that backups are not performed on ephemeral storage systems.

section.title: Volumes
section.para: As mentioned above, OpenStack provides two classes of block storage, “ephemeral” storage and persistent “volumes”. Ephemeral storage exists only for the life of an instance: it will persist across reboots of the guest operating system but when the instance is deleted so is the associated storage.

Volumes are instead persistent virtualized block devices independent of any particular instance. Volumes may be attached to a single instance at a time (i.e. not like a distributed filesystem such as Lustre or Gluster), but they may be detached or reattached to a different instance while retaining all data, much like a USB drive.
The steps to add a Volume are:

listitem.para: Define a disk volume of the size required (12GB in example below) with the volume name defined (testvol in the example below)
Attach that volume to the instance that you would like it to be available on
Log in to the instance and format/mount as required

section.para: To define a disk volume using the Dashboard, click on Volumes and then Create Volume. In the “Create Volume” window specify the name of the volume and the desired size. As Volume Source specify “No source, empty volume”.
The new defined volume will appear in the Volumes tab. To attach this volume to an existing instance, click on Edit attachments and select the relevant Virtual Machine.
Log into the VM. Check if the disk has been added:
If needed, create a file system on it (this will scratch the disk !):
To detach a volume from an instance, first of all log into the virtual machine that has the volume mounted, and unmount it:

Then, using the Dashboard, click on Volumes, click on Edit attachments for the relevant volume and select Detach Volume. The detached volume can then be associated to another VM, as described above (you won't have to re-create the file system, otherwise you will lose the content of the volume !)
If a volume is not needed any longer, to completely remove it (note that this step cannot be reverted!):

listitem.para: if needed, detach the volume from the associated instance
using the Dashboard, click on Volumes, select the relevant volume and then select Delete Volumes

warning.para: Please note that backups are not performed on volumes.
